review.title: STransE: a novel embedding model of entities and relationships in knowledge bases
review.abstract: Knowledge bases of real-world facts about entities and their relationships are useful resources for a variety of natural language processing tasks. However, because knowledge bases are typically incomplete, it is useful to be able to perform link prediction, i.e., predict whether a relationship not in the knowledge base is likely to be true. This paper combines insights from several previous link prediction models into a new embedding model STransE that represents each entity as a low-dimensional vector, and each relation by two matrices and a translation vector. STransE is a simple combination of the SE and TransE models, but it obtains better link prediction performance on two benchmark datasets than previous embedding models. Thus, STransE can serve as a new baseline for the more complex models in the link prediction task.
histories: Proceedings of NAACL-HLT 2016, pages 460-466. arXiv admin note: text overlap witharXiv:1606.06461
V1: In Proceedings of NAACL-HLT 2016. V2: Corrected citation to (Krompa{\ss} et al., 2015)

V1: In Proceedings of the 2016 Conference of the North American Chapter of the Association for Computational Linguistics: Human Language Technologies, NAACL HLT 2016. V2: Corrected citation to (Krompa{\ss} et al., 2015). V3: A revised version of our NAACL-HLT 2016 paper with additional experimental results and latest related work

metadata.title: STransE: a novel embedding model of entities and relationships in knowledge bases∗

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: There is a wide variety of information that is potentially useful, including information from outside companies (Riedel et al., 2013; Wang et al., 2015).

sections.heading: 2 Our approach
sections.text: For each threefold (h, r, t), in which h, t) of a plausible threefold (h, r, t), threefold (h, r, t), threefold (h, r, t), threefold (h, t), implausible (h, r, t), we define the STransE evaluation as follows: fr (h, r, t) = a plausible threefold (h, r, t), threefold (h, t), threefold (h, t), threefold (h, t), threefold (h, t), threefold (h, t), threefold (h, t), and in order to learn the vectors and matrices, we minimize the following margin-based target function: L = threefold (h, r, t), threefold (h, t), threefold (h, t), threefold (h, t), threefold (h, t), threefold (h, t), threefold (h, t), threefold (h, t), threefold (h, h), threefold (h, h, h), threefold (h, r, t), threefold (h, t), fourfold (h, t), fourfold (h), quadruefold (h, h), quadruefold (h, quadruple (h, h, h, h, h), fourefold (h, quadruple, quadruple, h, quadruple, h, h, h, h, h, h, h, h), fourfold, fourfold, fourfold (fourfold, h, h, h, h, h, h), fourfold, fourfold (fourfold),

sections.heading: 3 Related work
sections.text: The models differ in the score functions fr (h, t) and the algorithms for optimizing the margin-based objective function, e.g. SGD, AdaGrad (Duchi et al., 2011), AdaDelta (Zeiler, 2012) and L-BFGS (Liu and Nocedal, 1989). DISTMULT (Yang et al., 2015) is based on a bilinear model (Nickel et al., 2011; Bordes et al., 2012; Jenatton et al., 2012), where each relationship is represented by a diagonal rather than a complete matrix. The neural tensor network (NTN) is based on a bilinear model (Socher et al, 2013) uses a bilinear tensor operator to represent each relationship, while ProjE (Shi and Weninger, 2017) can be considered a simplified version of NTN with diagonal matrices. Similar forms to any dursor can be used.

sections.heading: 4 Experiments
sections.text: To evaluate the link prediction, we conduct experiments and compare the performance of our STransE model with the published results of the benchmark datasets WN18 and FB15k (Bordes et al., 2013). Information on these datasets is listed in Table 2.

sections.heading: 4.1 Task and evaluation protocol
sections.text: The linkage task (Bordes et al., 2011; Bordes et al., 2012; Bordes et al., 2013) predicts the head or tail entity given the ratio type and the other entity, i.e. the prediction given h (?, r, t) or the prediction given t (h, r,?) where? denotes the missing element. Results are evaluated by the ranking function fr (h, t) on the score function, which is referred to as the "Raw" setting protocol. For the "filtered" setting protocol described in Bordes et al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al al. (2013), we removed all corrupt triples that appear in the knowledge base to avoid cases where a corrupt triple could be ranked higher than the triple setting protocol.

sections.heading: 4.2 Main results
sections.text: Table 3 compares the link prediction results of our STransE model with results reported in previous work, using the same experimental setup. However, the first 15 lines report the performance of models that do not use information about alternative paths between head and tail units. The next 5 lines report the results of models that use information about relation paths. However, the last 3 lines present results for models that use textual mentions derived from a large external corpus. It is clear that models that do not use such information have the best results. In future work, we plan to expand the STransE model to include such additional information. Table 3 also shows that models that use path information generally achieve better results than models that do not use such information. In terms of models that do not use path information or external information, the STransE model produces the highest filtered mean on W18 and the highest transformational values on 15k and 1518 transformational waves.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion and future work
sections.text: This paper presented a new embedding model for link prediction and KB completion. Our STransE combines insights from several simpler embedding models, in particular the structured embedding model (Bordes et al., 2011) and the TransE model (Bordes et al., 2013), using a low-dimensional vector and two projection matrices to represent each relationship. STransE is conceptually simple, but delivers highly competitive results in standard link prediction assessments and performs better than the embedding-based models that build on it. Therefore, it is a suitable candidate for future base models in the link prediction task. In future work, we plan to extend STransE to the use of relationship path information in knowledge databases in a similar way to Lin et al. (2015a), Guu et al. (2015) or Nguyen et al. (2016).

sections.heading: Acknowledgments
sections.text: This research was supported by a Google Prize under the Natural Language Understanding Focused Program and the Australian Research Council's Discovery Projects Program (project number DP160102156). NICTA is funded by the Australian Government through the Department of Communications and the Australian Research Council through the ICT Centre of Excellence Program. The first author is supported by an International Postgraduate Research Scholarship and a NICTA NRPA Top-Up Scholarship.

metadata.abstractText: Knowledge bases of real-world facts about entities and their relationships are useful resources for a variety of natural language processing tasks. However, because knowledge bases are typically incomplete, it is useful to be able to perform link prediction or knowledge base completion, i.e., predict whether a relationship not in the knowledge base is likely to be true. This paper combines insights from several previous link prediction models into a new embedding model STransE that represents each entity as a low-dimensional vector, and each relation by two matrices and a translation vector. STransE is a simple combination of the SE and TransE models, but it obtains better link prediction performance on two benchmark datasets than previous embedding models. Thus, STransE can serve as a new baseline for the more complex models in the link prediction task.
